item.title: [Pavia, Italy] A Day in Pavia
item.description:
Welcome to Pavia! Pavia, Italy

Home to an ancient university, the town of Pavia dates back to pre-Roman times when it was known as Ticinum.

Our train-happy family readily jumped onto a train at Milan Centrale to spend a day at Pavia. A day of discoveringÂ piazzas, a university, and beautiful churches.

 

Our walk began from the train station at Pavia. We ambled along the streets that led to Piazza della Vittoria and the quiet Piazza del Duomo. It was summer and a sense of emptiness prevailed. Residents and studentsÂ had probably left for the seaside, as many Italians doÂ during the hot season. A few cyclists rode through the town, pausing to gaze at theÂ beautiful landmarks.

 

Streets of Pavia. Italy

Pavia, Italy

At Piazza del Duomo, we found a cool spot in the shade, ideal for a leisurely lunch. Later, I was even ready for a siesta, but the boys were eager to continue exploring the town, and pulled me out ofÂ my comfortable seat.

Cathedral of Pavia (Duomo di Pavia). Italy

Cathedral of Pavia (Duomo di Pavia). Italy

As the sun shone bright and hot, we resumed our walk and headedÂ toward the river Ticino. And the lovely Ponte Coperto (covered bridge) provided a much-needed respite from the heat. Along the sandy patches on the river bank, people seemed to be enjoyingÂ the sunshineÂ (of course, they had the option of diving into the cool water when the heat got unbearable).

 

Ponte Coperto,Â Pavia. Italy

Cooling off in the summer heat. River Ticino, Pavia, Italy

Onward to the basilica of San Michele Maggiore, a striking sandstone structure from the 12th century. After a brief halt at the church, we decided to pursue academic interests, and set off to explore the campus of the renowned University of Pavia.

 

Basilica of San Michele Maggiore. Pavia, Italy

Basilica of San Michele Maggiore. Pavia, Italy

Founded in 1361, the University of Pavia boasts of many distinguished alumni and scientists, including Alessandro Volta and Camillo Golgi. The campus was quiet owing to the holidays,Â and, as we walked around, it was a humbling experience to learn about the numerous Nobel Prize winners associated with the university. Three medieval towers rise high in Piazza Leonardo da Vinci, symbols of an era gone by, reminders of the rich history of Pavia.

 

Alessandro Volta. University of Pavia, Italy

Standing tall. Medieval Towers. Pavia, Italy

On our way back to the station, we made plans to return to Pavia (to visit the grand Certosa di Pavia).

 

More ideas for day trips from Milan:

============================

Bergamo:Â http://funderfulworld.com/thetravelbug/bergamo-beyond-the-airport-citta-alta/

Peschiera del Garda:Â http://funderfulworld.com/thetravelbug/bidding-summer-goodbye-at-peschiera-del-garda/

Ferrari Museum at Modena:Â http://funderfulworld.com/thetravelbug/men-machines-movies-maranello-at-the-ferrari-museum/

Bologna:Â http://funderfulworld.com/thetravelbug/an-afternoon-walk-through-bolognas-beautiful-porticoes/

Varenna:Â http://funderfulworld.com/thetravelbug/a-dreamy-day-in-varenna/

Lecco:Â http://funderfulworld.com/thetravelbug/a-sunny-day-in-lecco/

Vigevano:Â http://funderfulworld.com/thetravelbug/vigevano-few-tourists-loads-of-charm/

item.title: [Milan, Italy] Monte Stella: The Hill with a View of Milan
item.description:
Monte Stella. Milan, Italy

If you are weary from sightseeing and shopping in Milan, and are looking for a tranquil setting, head to the lovely Monte Stella. Condition: You would need a little bit of energy to hike up the hill :).

If you are a fitness enthusiast, you could jog alongÂ the pathÂ here.

Monte Stella is a verdant locationÂ with various paths leading around and up the hill. ThisÂ artificial hill was created from rubble resulting from WWII damage.

A short walk from theÂ MM1 metro station QT8Â took us to the base of the hill. The bright sunshineÂ andÂ clear blue sky provided a perfect setting for our enthusiastic hike along the little paths. It was difficultÂ to believe that this serene hill was located in the busy capital of Lombardy. After several halts to closely examine insects and inhabitants of the park, we reached the top. At the summit, we gazed in various directions to (correctly) identify familiarÂ landmarks in Milan.

Take the stairs! Monte Stella, Milan, Italy

Where the path leads… Monte Stella, Milan, Italy

View of Milan from Monte Stella. Milan, Italy

Later, we settled on a bench with a view and munched on our picnic lunch. Ah, the pleasures of a picnic lunch after a hike :D!

With the hunger pangs satisfied, it was time for our descent.

But it wasn’t time to return home yet! The children’s play area at the base of Monte StellaÂ had a hugeÂ “Welcome, Junior” sign. Well, almost :).

So, after a long play session, we finally headed to QT8 station for the return ride home.

As far as the eye can see. From Monte Stella, Milan, Italy

Monte Stella is a lovely oasis of serenityÂ in Milan. Now that spring is here, bask in the sunshine atop the hill!

item.title: Trieste: Exploring the City
item.description:
Admire Trieste and its breathtaking surroundings from above by followingÂ theÂ scenic trailÂ along the Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica).

And then, walk some more to explore this city along the Adriatic Sea. Go ahead, it’s the best way to discover Trieste!

 

Rooftops. Trieste, Italy

An Evening Walk in Trieste:

Our evening stroll through the city took us to Piazza San Giovanni, Piazza Sant’Antonio, andÂ the beautiful Serbian Orthodox church of San Spiridione.
The picturesque Canal Grande was buzzingÂ with activity. We ambled through the market along the canal and bought ‘fruit bread’ from Austria, a delicious treat for our growling stomachs.Â We then proceeded along the seaside to the pier Molo Audace, a lovely spot to gaze out at the sea. With gelatos in hand! ðŸ™‚

Chiesa di Sant’Antonio Nuovo. Trieste, Italy 

<p class="wp-caption-text">
  The Church of San Spiridione. Trieste, Italy
</p>


<p class="wp-caption-text">
  The Canal Grande. Trieste, Italy
</p>

Our next halt was at the magnificentÂ Piazza Unita d’Italia. This piazza that opens out to the sea is surrounded by many beautiful buildings. Junior would have loved to play in the vast square but he was tired after ourÂ long walk along the Strada Vicentina earlier that day.

 

We admired the architecture of the buildings, walked along the seafront, and watched studentsÂ diveÂ into the Adriatic.

 

The beautiful seafront. Trieste, Italy

Piazza UnitÃ  d’Italia. Trieste, Italy

The waterfront from Piazza UnitÃ  d’Italia. Trieste, Italy

 

From the modern to the ancient. On to the Via del Teatro Romano and the ruins of theÂ Teatro Romano (Roman Theater). The theater, dating back to the 1st and 2nd century AD, lies at the foot of the San Giusto hill. Junior was delighted to see a cat in the vicinity and suddenly, his fatigue disappeared. The ‘miaow’ conversation was animated and quite hilarious to the onlookers.

 

Teatro Romano (Roman Theater). Trieste, Italy

MIAOW! Trieste, Italy

A Morning Walk in Trieste:

On a bright sunny morning, we passed Piazza Goldoni and climbed the Scala dei Giganti, pausing often to smell the flowers, share a joke, look back at the rooftops of Trieste. Atop the hill, we crossedÂ the drawbridge to enter the Castello di San Giusto (San Giusto Castle).

Junior was drawn toÂ the cannonsÂ while we were impressed by the statues of Michez and Jachez who sound the hour.

The castle, builtÂ primarily of stone, offers splendid views of the numerous hills around Trieste, the shimmering blue Gulf of Trieste, and the lovely red rooftops of the city.Â We thoroughly enjoyed walking across the huge courtyard and on the ramparts, peering through the gaps in the walls, counting the hills in the distance, and gazing at the sailboats.

 

Climbing the Scala dei Giganti. Trieste, Italy

Up! Scala dei Giganti, Trieste, Italy

Michez and Jachez. San Giusto Castle, Trieste, Italy

San Giusto Castle. Trieste, Italy

San Giusto Castle. Trieste, Italy

After a brief visit to the Cattedrale di San Giusto (San Giusto Cathedral) across the castle, we headed toÂ Parco della Rimembranza. Junior loved the play area in the vicinity.

 

Cathedral of San Giusto. Trieste, Italy

It was time to bid farewell to Trieste after an enjoyable weekend.

If you visit Trieste,Â put on your comfortable walking shoes, step out, and discover the charms of this beautiful city.

item.title: Scenic Walking Trails: The Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica) at Trieste
item.description:
As far as I can see. Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica), Trieste, Italy

Welcome to Trieste, the capital of Friuli Venezia Giulia, an autonomous region in Italy. This vibrant city in the north-east part of the country exhibitsÂ a mix of Italian, Slovenian, German, and other cultures. ItÂ is theÂ home of Illy coffee – reason enough to indulge in a cuppa Joe!

FrecciaBianca trains offer direct connectionsÂ between Milan and Trieste, via Venice. Thus, Trieste found an entry in our travel planner.

 

Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica): Get set go!

One of the most scenic trails that we have ever walked along is the Strada Vicentina or Strada Napoleonica at Trieste. An easy pedestrian route, convenient for prams and strollers, offers spectacular views of the Gulf of Trieste. The panorama of the rooftops of Trieste below, the shimmering Adriatic Sea beyond, and the Istrian islands in the distance make this trail a favorite among visitors.

Strada Vicentina, Trieste, Italy

The tram to Opicina was not operational, and so, we took a bus from Piazza Oberdan in the direction ofÂ Opicina, and alighted at the Obelisk.

The Obelisk above the city of TriesteÂ is a fine structure erected in the 1800s. It marks the start of the beautiful Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica), named after the engineer who was responsible for its construction.

Take a few hours to stroll along this trail, and pause oftenÂ to admire the breathtaking views, observe the vegetation (mainly pines), gaze at the seemingly endless stretch of sea, find peace and tranquility.

We began our walkÂ at the Obelisk. Junior loves morning hikes, and led the way along the trail. Soon, we caught sight of the city of Trieste below. The sea was calm, a few boatsÂ sailed forth to their respective destinations. I was excited to see the Istrian islands in the distance, a trip for another day.

The lighthouse, Faro della Vittoria, made a pretty picture from up above. We took short breaks every now and then, admiringÂ the vistas, dreaming of distant lands, examining lizards and rocks, ambling along, running a bit, sitting quietly, chatting excitedly.

The Miramare Castle stood in solitude below, a white structure on the shore. We passed rocky cliffs, where enthusiastsÂ were getting ready for the challenging climb.

Obelisk. Trieste, Italy

From the Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica). Trieste, Italy

Faro della Vittoria. Seen from Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica), Trieste, Italy

Go where the trail leads. Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica), Trieste, Italy

Along the trail. Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica), Trieste, Italy

Cliffs. Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica), Trieste, Italy

Trieste from above. Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica), Trieste, Italy

At this point, the “almost flat” pedestrian trail forked, one pathÂ led to Prosecco and the other path, aÂ “forest” trail, CAI 12, looped back through another route to take us to the point where we started our hike.

We chose the trail through the forest, carefully following the signs for the marked route, CAI 12. Ascending the path, after a while, we reached the observation point, Vedetta Italia. This placeÂ offers splendid views all around. We had walked for more than a couple of hours now, and decided to take a lunch break here. Picnic lunch over, Junior seemed enthusiastic to continue the hike.

We followedÂ the trail and were in for a treat. Soon, we were at the beautiful and unique Santuario Nazionale a Maria Madre e Regina. The trapezoidal structure of the church towers high above Trieste, and is visible from the city. The sanctuary is an oasis of peace. We visited the church, explored the garden, and couldn’t resist stoppingÂ at the cafe here :).

Along CAI 12. Trieste, Italy

View of Trieste from Santuario di Monte Grisa. Trieste, Italy

Santuario Nazionale a Maria Madre e Regina (Tempio di Monte Grisa). Trieste, Italy

The church seen from Trieste. Santuario Nazionale a Maria Madre e Regina (Tempio di Monte Grisa). Trieste, Italy

It had been several hours since the start of our hike, and Junior was visibly tired. We decided to take the bus back to Trieste from here.

It is possible to continue on the trail from the church, and reach the Obelisk, the starting point of our walk. On our list for next time! ðŸ™‚

This scenic walking trail, the Strada Vicentina (Strada Napoleonica), was the highlight of our visit to Trieste. Junior talks about it excitedly even today!

 

Useful Information:

– Take the tram or bus from Piazza Oberdan to Opicina, and alight at the Obelisk. The trail starts from the Obelisk.

– A detailed and useful descriptionÂ of the routeÂ and trail directions in Italian can be found hereÂ and here.

 

Related Posts on FunderfulWorld:

Trieste: Exploring the City

{.entry-title}

item.title: Stresa: Villas, Islands, and a Beautiful Lakeside Promenade
item.description:
Lake Maggiore. Stresa, Italy

Stresa, on the shores of the large Lake Maggiore, is a quick, easy, and beautiful weekend getaway from Milan. With a train journey of about an hour, StresaÂ could even be the destination of a day trip from the fashion capital.

We conversed with garden lizards and Amherst pheasants at the beautiful Isola Madre, strolled along Stresa’s lovely lakeside promenade, sighed over the views from the public park, and petted farm animals in the gardens at the Villa Pallavicino.

 

Explore the Borromean Islands: Isola Madre, Stresa

The Borromean Islands (Isola Bella, Isola Madre, and Isola dei Pescatori) are accessible by ferry from Stresa.

Our weekend in Stresa got off to a great start atÂ one of the islands, Isola Madre. We followed the walking trail, stopping to gaze at the pretty views and the tall trees every now and then, while Junior paused often to chat with the lizards and other garden inhabitants. An encounter with Amherst pheasants and peacocks had Junior jumping with joy, andÂ the sight of a quaint island cafe with the loveliest view made my day!

At Isola Madre. Stresa, Italy

Inhabitant of Isola Madre. Stresa, Italy

Isola Madre. Stresa, Italy

View from Isola Madre. Stresa, Italy

 

Walk the Walk: Lakeside Promenade, Stresa

A pleasant evening stroll along Stresa’s beautifulÂ lakeside promenade brought us to a public garden with a kids’ play area. Junior rushed to join the enthusiastic kids prancing around. For his parents, the parkÂ was a perfect location to unwind at the end of a great day. The calm waters of the lake, the towering mountains in the distance, the snow-capped peaks beyond, and theÂ occasional boat entering the landscapeÂ made the picture more than perfect.

Along the lake. Stresa, Italy

Lakeside Promenade. Stresa, Italy

 

Sunday Fun at Villa Pallavicino

A morning walk through the narrow streets of Stresa revealed the many charms of the small town.

Look what we found! In the streets of Stresa, Italy

Later, we boarded the treno turistico (tourist train)Â toÂ the entrance ofÂ the Villa Pallavicino park. This green oasis also houses a small zoological park. Junior was thrilled to pet the goats and deerÂ butÂ we were wary of the llamas. When hunger pangs struck, a restaurant in the same premises came to our rescue. The long walk through the garden offersÂ picturesque views of the lake and snow-capped mountains. When it was time to leave, I had to tear myself away from several such locations.

However, as a reward to ourselves,Â we managedÂ a last walk (slightly hurried, but lovely, nevertheless) along the lakeside promenade before heading to the train station.

Hop on! The tourist train. Stresa, Italy

Kids and more! At the Villa Pallavicino, Stresa, Italy

The gardens at the Villa Pallavicino. Stresa, Italy

The gardens at the Villa Pallavicino. Stresa, Italy

 

Do visit Stresa! ðŸ™‚

 

UsefulÂ information:

http://www.visitstresa.com/

Ferry timetable:Â http://www.navigazionelaghi.it/

Where we stayed: Hotel Primavera, Stresa

item.title: Bergamo Beyond the Airport: CittÃ Alta
item.description:
The city of Bergamo, located at the foothills of the Alps, finds its place on many itineraries owing to its airport. Given the chance (and the time),Â it is a beautiful “two-tiered” city to visit. Frequent trains connect Bergamo and Milan, making it a fantastic destination for a day trip from the fashion capital.

 

Over the rooftops and towers. Bergamo, Italy.

On a sunny spring morning, about a year ago, we spent a day exploringÂ the beautiful CittÃ  Alta of Bergamo.

A pleasant walk (of approximately aÂ kilometer) from Bergamo station past several pretty piazzas brought us to theÂ funicular that would take us from CittÃ  Bassa to CittÃ  Alta, up the hill.

 

In CittÃ  Bassa. Bergamo, Italy

Looking up at CittÃ  Alta. Bergamo, Italy

 

Piazza Vecchia, in the Historic Center

We loved strolling throughÂ the narrow cobbled streets of the CittÃ  Alta to reachÂ the Piazza Vecchia. The impressive Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore, the Colleoni Chapel,Â the Baptistery, andÂ the Palazzo della Ragione are a feast for the eyes! After appreciating the Medieval and Rennaisance architecture, take a ride up the elevator of theÂ bell tower,Â Torre Civica (or Campanone), for splendid views over Bergamo. The bell in this tower tolls 100 times every night at 10 pm (unfortunately, we visited during the day, and did not get a chance to hear it).

Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore. Bergamo, Italy

Where the bell tolls. The Belltower (Torre Civica or Campanone), Bergamo, Italy

Piazza Vecchia from the bell tower. Bergamo, Italy

Frame it! From the bell tower at Bergamo, Italy

Watching over. Bergamo, Italy

 

And we saved the best for last!

La Rocca and Parco delle Rimembranze,Â LookingÂ Near and Far

The complex of La Rocca and the Parco delle Rimembranze offers the most delightful views of the area. We sang praises of the views over the towers and domes of Bergamo,Â whileÂ JuniorÂ hummed a happy tune as he scampered around a bright yellow tank in the park.

La Rocca. Bergamo, Italy

Grab a seat! At the Parco delle Rimembranze. Bergamo, Italy

Nestled in the foothills. View from Parco delle Rimembranze, Bergamo, Italy.

Sunshine. Parco delle Rimembranze, Bergamo, Italy.

 

Sweet Tooth

During our stroll in the city, we could not resist trying the Polenta e Osei, a special dessert from Bergamo.

 

Take a bite! Polenta e Osei. Bergamo, Italy

item.title: Rome: A Morning at Gianicolo (Janiculum) Hill
item.description:
Take a walk! Passeggiata del Gianicolo, Gianicolo Hill, Rome, Italy

For a slice of tranquilityÂ and a different perspective of Rome, we spent a morning atÂ the Gianicolo (Janiculum) Hill, hadÂ lunch in the charming Trastevere neighborhood, and strolled along the Ponte Sisto.

 

We boardedÂ a busÂ that halted near the Piazzale del Faro. The Faro al Gianicolo (Lighthouse) in this piazza was a gift from Argentina to Italy. From here, we walkedÂ along the Passeggiata del Gianicolo that leads to the hilltop. On the way, the equestrian monument of the brave Anita Garibaldi stands tall. At Piazzale Giuseppe Garibaldi, a monument to the hero dominates the square. Incredible views of Rome stretch out below the Gianicolo hill, and weÂ spent some time trying to identify the innumerable monuments inÂ Italy’s capital. On the other side, do not miss the special views of St. Peter’s Basilica.

The Gianicolo Hill, the site of a battle between Garibaldi and the French troops, is an oasis of green today. At the top, busts of many brave men who defended ItalyÂ dot the landscape.

The Magnificent City of Rome. From Gianicolo Hill, Rome, Italy

Anita Garibaldi. Gianicolo Hill, Rome, Italy

Where’s the sky? Tree-lined path. Gianicolo Hill, Rome, Italy

Giuseppe Garibaldi. At Gianicolo Hill, Rome, Italy

The Brave. Gianicolo Hill, Rome, Italy

Heading to the city? Gianicolo Hill, Rome, Italy

Behind the trees. St. Peter’s Basilica. From Gianicolo Hill, Rome, Italy

 

We enjoyedÂ walking along the tree-linedÂ pathsÂ andÂ gazing at the panoramic views of this magnificent city. In this serene location, Junior was actively engaged with pebbles, sticks and the bark of trees, while B and I mused over the magic of Rome. A city we always look forward to visiting. And each time, we toss a coin into the Trevi fountain, hoping to return to Rome.

After a satisfyingÂ lunch at a restaurant in the charming Trastevere neighborhood, we ambled along the quaint streets of the area before heading to the Ponte Sisto over the River Tiber.Â This bridge offers pretty views of the Gianicolo hill and St. Peter’s Basilica.

 

Bridge over the River Tiber (Tevere). View from Ponte Sisto, Rome, Italy

item.title: A Trip to Padua
item.description:
Prato della Valle. Padua, Italy

Padua, a city in close proximity to the Queen of the Adriatic, Venice, appears to live in the shadow of its more “popular” neighbor.

During our weekend escape to Padua, we discovered a charming cityÂ thatÂ boasts of a renowned university (dating back to 1222) whose alumni and professors list includes Galileo Galilei, CopernicusÂ andÂ William Harvey. The world’s first university botanical garden finds its home here, and features in the UNESCO heritage list. Many pilgrims visit the beautiful basilica of St. Anthony of Padua. A large part of Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew is based in this city.

 

Here’s what we loved aboutÂ Padua:

B’s favorite pick would, most certainly,Â beÂ the basilicaÂ of St. AnthonyÂ of Padua, also known as Il Santo.

We walked through porticoes in the streetsÂ to reach the shrine and admire its tranquil interior. The cupolas of this basilica adorn the skyline of Padua and make for beautiful postcard images.Â The statue of a horse and its rider in the square outside is one of Donatello’s creations.

Basilica of St. Anthony of Padua. Padua, Italy

Basilica of St. Anthony of Padua. Padua, Italy

Basilica of St. Anthony of Padua. Padua, Italy

 

Junior would undoubtedly chooseÂ the Botanical Garden.

From delicate flowering plants to fascinating carnivorous ones, the Botanical Garden of Padua is home to a vast collection. Here, we spottedÂ the alpine Himalayan Cedar, peeredÂ (not too closely)Â at the poisonous plantsÂ andÂ examined the rare species. Take a break at the Fountain of the Four Seasons,Â enjoy aÂ walk up the little hillock in the garden, marvel at nature.

 

Botanical Garden. Padua, Italy

Botanical Garden. Padua, Italy

Pitcher plant. Carnivorous plants at the Botanical Garden of Padua, Italy

Take a walk. Botanical Garden of Padua, Italy

Botanical Garden of Padua, Italy

 

I thoroughly enjoyed our relaxedÂ walksÂ in the city

Padua is best explored on foot. Ambling along the littleÂ canals, admiring theÂ pretty bridges, pausing for a gelato in the lively piazzas… we were in no hurry! ðŸ™‚

Bicycles on a bridge. Padua, Italy

Looking good in green. Padua, Italy

Canal in Padua, Italy

 

What is the time? Astronomical clock, Piazza dei Signori, Padua, Italy

The Prato della Valle had everyone’s vote!

After a long day of sightseeing, the Prato della Valle was a perfect location to just sit back and relax. This vast green expanse surrounded by a canal lined with statues is popular with visitors. Play a game of football, bask in the sun, read a book or take a leisurely stroll in this largeÂ square. If time permits, you could visit the beautiful Basilica of Santa Giustina nearby.

 

Prato della Valle. Padua, Italy

Prato della Valle and the Santa Giustina basilica. Padua, Italy

Prato della Valle. Padua, Italy

On our next visit, we would probably see Giotto’s frescoes at the Scrovegni Chapel and Mantegna’s work in the Eremitani church.

item.title: A Weekend in Verona: From Romans to Romance
item.description:
Roman Arena. Verona, Italy

From the beautiful Roman Arena to theÂ romanticÂ atmosphereÂ inspired by Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet, a weekend in VeronaÂ can be memorable. The Adige river winds its way through this beautiful city in the Veneto region of Italy.

We “exercised”Â our feet at the Arena, ambledÂ alongÂ in Piazza Bra and Piazza delle Erbe, smiled at the fuss aboutÂ “Juliet’s balcony”, wandered in the maze at Giardino Giusti, and enjoyed a tranquilÂ evening stroll along the River Adige.

 

TheÂ RomanÂ Arena:

The Roman Arena, built in theÂ first century AD, is aÂ venue for many concerts and operas (especially in the summer). We explored the well-preserved interior, walkedÂ up and down the high steps, watched the activity inÂ Piazza Bra from the “viewpoints”Â andÂ “pretended” to watch an opera. Junior was thrilled with the climbing and counting (steps), and his adrenalin was at an all-time high.

 

Inside the Arena. Verona, Italy

Inside the Arena. Verona, Italy

Piazza Bra from the Arena. Verona, Italy.

Piazza delle Erbe:

A perfect place for a gelato break! Some buildings in the Piazza delle ErbeÂ are adorned with beautiful frescoes. Fountains, statues, cafes and restaurants make a pretty picture. AÂ whale rib hanging from the Arco della CostaÂ adds a touch of intrigue.

 

The Winged Lion. At Piazza delle Erbe, Verona, Italy

Beautiful frescoes. At Piazza delle Erbe, Verona, Italy

Whale rib. Arco della Costa, Verona, Italy

Romeo and Juliet:

With all the buzz about the Montagues and the Capulets, we succumbed toÂ the temptation of viewingÂ Juliet’s balcony (yes, we know it isn’t THE balcony, but we were curiousÂ :)). Verona abounds in “Romeo and Juliet” attractions;Â however,Â this was the only one that we visited. The huge crowds at Casa di Giulietta (Juliet’s house) areÂ a testimony to the popularity of Shakespeare’s tale (especially the “romance” associated with it). A huge whiteboard allows lovebirds to write their messages to Juliet (in an effort to reduce the graffiti at this location).

 

Love locks. Casa di Giulietta (Juliet’s House), Verona, Italy

Juliet’s balcony. Casa di Giulietta (Juliet’s House), Verona, Italy

Write on White. Casa di Giulietta (Juliet’s House), Verona, Italy

Giardino Giusti:

Our mandatory “green escape” was a visitÂ to the lovely Giardino Giusti.

Junior rushed toÂ the maze near the entrance. He had an excitingÂ time findingÂ his way throughÂ the labyrinth. The serenity of the garden, with its fountains and cypress trees, was a welcome changeÂ from the buzzÂ of the city. You can get up close and personal with the mascherone, and then, headÂ up the slopes for lovely views of Verona from the top.

We could not leave before spending quality timeÂ with the turtles and fish in the pond! And a few more attempts atÂ losing (and finding) our way in the maze :).

 

Lose your way! The maze at Giardino Giusti, Verona, Italy

Where the path leads us. Giardino Giusti, Verona, Italy

Welcome! The “mascherone” at Giardino Giusti, Verona, Italy

The city of Verona. From Giardino Giusti, Verona, Italy

Walks and More:

An evening walk along the banks of the river, with pretty views of the Castel Vecchio and Ponte Scaligero at sunset, was a great way to end the day.

And aÂ stroll along the Ponte Pietra, a Roman arch bridge across the River Adige, was an awesome way toÂ begin the next.

 

Along the River Adige. Verona, Italy

Along the River Adige. Verona, Italy

Thus, weÂ discovered (first-hand), the charm ofÂ Verona. And now, I can’t wait to read The Taming of the Shrew, The Two Gentlemen of Verona, and perhaps,Â Romeo and Juliet… Or better still, write a story… Based in Verona. Food for thought!

item.title: Postcards and Stories from Milan: Piazzas in the City â€“ II
item.description:
After that introduction to some of the piazzas in Milan, here are some of my other favorites: Â  Piazza Cordusio Surrounded by beautiful bank buildings, this oval-shaped piazza in the heart of Milan is almost always teeming with activity. Sometimes, I pauseÂ here, watch the trams go by, peer at the Castello Sforzesco in the distance and then takeÂ a short walk along the lively pedestrian street, Via dei Mercanti, that leads to the Duomo.

Piazza Cordusio, Milan, Italy

Piazza Cordusio, Milan, Italy

Via dei Mercanti, Milan, Italy

Piazza Monumentale The towering monuments of the large cemetery, Cimitero Monumentale, dominate the skyline near this square. Several trams stop nearÂ the piazza.Â Visit the Cimitero Monumentale, or head to Via Paolo Sarpi, the Chinatown of Milano, a short distance away.

Cimitero Monumentale, Milan, Italy

Piazza Santa Maria delle Grazie Signs and directions to this square are visible in the entire area. The primary reason: hordes of tourists come looking for the Church of Santa Maria delle Grazie, and Leonardo da Vinci’s original Last Supper painting housed in the refectory of the convent. Much of the church suffered damage during World War II. However, the famous painting miraculously survived, and the church has been restored. The piazzaÂ is a beautiful locationÂ to cool your heels while admiring the exterior architecture of the church and convent. For Last Supper (Cenacolo Vinciano in Italian) viewing, tickets can be booked in advanceÂ onÂ this website. On many a spring day, I’ve basked in the sunshine here.

Piazza Santa Maria delle Grazie, Milan, Italy

The church of Santa Maria delle Grazie, Piazza Santa Maria delle Grazie, Milan, Italy

Piazza del Carmine In the charming Brera district, the Piazza del Carmine never fails to take my breath away. The lovelyÂ Church of Santa Maria del Carmine is a beautiful sight, andÂ a uniqueÂ sculpture in the piazza draws considerable attention. A few cafes offer seating outdoors. The pretty flowers in the windows overlooking the piazzaÂ add to the charm factor. I often spend a few tranquil minutes in this square, and then stroll along one of the quaint little streets ofÂ Brera.

Piazza del Carmine, Milan, Italy

Flowers. Piazza del Carmine, Milan, Italy

Flowers. Piazza del Carmine, Milan, Italy

Piazza Gae Aulenti In the business district, the Piazza Gae Aulenti shows off its skyscrapers and swanky office buildings. The fountains add a ‘charm’ quotient. In December, a tall Christmas tree shines bright in the square. Piazza Gae Aulenti, named after the well-known Italian architect, is situated near Porta Garibaldi station, a major transport hub in Milan. This is one of Junior’s favorite piazzas in the city.

Christmas tree. Piazza Gae Aulenti, Milan, Italy

Piazza Castello The “wedding cake” fountain and the backdropÂ of the Castello Sforzesco make this a picture-postcard square. As the sun sets, the lights at the castle make it even more special. The Piazza Castello area is being transformed into a pedestrian zone (for Expo 2015).

Piazza Castello, Milan, Italy

Piazza Castello, Milan, Italy

item.title: Postcards and Stories from Milan: Piazzas in the City â€“ I
item.description:
I often set off onÂ long walks in Milan. And on every such promenade, I look forward to a short break in a beautiful piazza. From the grand Piazza del Duomo to the pleasantÂ Piazza del Carmine, each square has a story, a vibrance, and a charm of its own. Some are crowdedÂ withÂ excited touristsÂ and buzzing with activity, others are quiet and offer a tranquil getawayÂ from the former.

 

Piazza del Duomo

This spectacular piazza, dominated by the grand Duomo of Milan, is a focal point for visitors to Milan. Visit the beautiful church (you can even climb to the top and walk among the spires), spend time at an art exhibition atÂ the Palazzo Reale, or shop at the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele. If you prefer the outdoors, grab a delicious panzerotto or two from the “oh-so-popular”Â LuiniÂ nearby(do not let the queue outside deter you, it moves very quickly),Â choose your favorite spotÂ in the square, and enjoy your meal. The Piazza del Duomo is, occasionally, a venue for concerts and exhibitions. In December, a gigantic Christmas tree finds pride of place here.

Junior loves the open space and innumerable pigeons in the square.

 

Piazza del Duomo, Milan, Italy

Piazza del Duomo, Milan, Italy

Galleria Vittorio Emanuele. Piazza del Duomo, Milan, Italy

View from the top of the Duomo. Piazza del Duomo, Milan, Italy

Piazza della Scala

A short walk from the Piazza del Duomo through the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele, leads to the smaller Piazza della Scala. Milan’sÂ renowned opera theatre, Teatro alla Scala (or simply, La Scala), is this square’s claim to fame. A statue of Leonarda da Vinci stands tall in the center of the square, andÂ the edifices of the Palazzo Marino and the Banca Commerciale Italiana dominate one side.

IÂ have optedÂ forÂ a _panzerotto_Â break in this square on a few occasions.

 

Piazza della Scala, Milan, Italy

Leonardo da Vinci. At Piazza della Scala, Milan, Italy

Piazza della Scala, Milan, Italy

Piazza San Babila

“Shop until you drop” at Corso Vittorio Emanuele II, a long pedestrian street leading from Piazza del Duomo to Piazza San Babila. In thisÂ fashion district, dozens of stores greet excited shoppers and no trip to Milan would be complete without some designer labels in hand. “Weary from” or “wary of” shopping? The Piazza San Babila, at the other end ofÂ this street, boasts of aÂ couple of fountains and the little church of San Babila across the square.

Every now and then, I strollÂ along Corso Vittorio Emanuele II and take a short break at this piazza, before hopping into the metro at San Babila metro station.

Corso Vittorio Emanuele II, Milan, Italy

 

Piazza San Babila, Milan, Italy

Piazza San Babila, Milan, Italy

Piazzale Cadorna

The Cadorna station is a major transport hub in Milan. The Malpensa express (withÂ connectivity to Milan’s Malpensa airport) and various suburban trains start (or end, depending on your perspective) their journey here. Two majorÂ metro lines (red M1 and green M2) pass through Cadorna. It is no wonder, then, that Piazzale Cadorna is always buzzing with activity – commuters hurrying to and from work, visitorsÂ arriving from or leaving forÂ the airport,Â and otherÂ folks like meÂ enjoying the melodious notes played by musicians in the square.

The Ago, Filo e Nodo (Needle, Thread and Knot) sculpture is a unique attraction of Piazzale Cadorna.

 

Piazzale Cadorna, Milan, Italy

Piazzale Cadorna, Milan, Italy

Piazza Duca d’Aosta

Just outside the magnificent Central Station (Stazione Centrale) of Milan, lies the Piazza Duca d’Aosta. Amid the travellers rushing to board a train and tourists clicking photographs of the huge impressive structure of the station,Â youngsters try their hand at skateboarding in the square.

Considering Junior’s fascination for “train-watching” and our umpteenÂ visits to Stazione Centrale, this square is among our “most-visited” spots in Milan.

Piazza Duca D’Aosta, Milan, Italy

Piazza Duca D’Aosta, Milan, Italy

Milan Central Station. Piazza Duca D’Aosta, Milan, Italy

 

 

More on piazzas in Milan in the nextÂ post!

item.title: In Pisa: A Date (or Two) with the Tower that Leans
item.description:
The One that Leans. The Leaning Tower, Piazza dei Miracoli, Pisa.

River Arno. Pisa, Italy

On a cool, grey evening in Pisa, we walked along a pleasant route beginning at theÂ Piazza Vittorio Emanuele, past the shopping area along Corso Italia, crossing the calm waters of the River Arno, continuing along Borgo Stretto, briefly halting at Piazza dei Cavalieri, before reaching our destination.

The Piazza dei Miracoli. The Square of Miracles. Also known as the Piazza del Duomo. I was awe-struck by the size and the beauty of the piazza and its monuments, and was remindedÂ of my first glimpse of the Taj Mahal. The cloudyÂ skies and intermittent drizzle had probably kept the crowds away from this extremelyÂ popular tourist attraction that evening and we were secretly thrilled about it.

The Leaning Tower, the Duomo, the Baptistery, and the CampoSanto dominate the square (aÂ UNESCO world heritage site),Â while the lush green grass lends a delightful contrast to the white structures. Junior was terribly disappointed that he had to keep off the grass here. Several visitorsÂ (who had not let the weather dampen their spirits) struck the weirdest poses with the Leaning Tower, and were quite an attractionÂ themselves :).

The CampoSanto, the Duomo, and the Leaning Tower. Piazza dei Miracoli, Pisa

The Duomo and the Leaning Tower, Piazza dei Miracoli, Pisa

The Duomo, Piazza dei Miracoli, Pisa

The Duomo. Piazza dei Miracoli, Pisa

The Baptistery, Piazza Dei Miracoli, Pisa

The Baptistery, Piazza Dei Miracoli, Pisa

The Baptistery, Piazza Dei Miracoli, Pisa

 

The One that Leans. The Leaning Tower, Piazza dei Miracoli, Pisa.

The Leaning Tower (Torre Pendente) of Pisa, which is the bell tower of the cathedral, is undoubtedlyÂ the main crowd-puller. However, the other beautiful monuments in the square deserve as much attention. Well, we were back in the Piazza dei MiracoliÂ the next day for a ‘morning view’ :).

item.title: In â€œPIZZAâ€ City, Napoli
item.description:
In the shadow of Mount Vesuvius. Sometimes grey, sometimes bright. Naples (Napoli), Italy

The city of “authentic” pizza margherita, Napoli (or Naples),Â has a remarkable identity of its own. Great food (read PIZZA :)), spectacular views ofÂ the Gulf of NaplesÂ andÂ the majestic Mount Vesuvius, a beautiful historic center, and the delightful nativity scenes and figurines in a vibrant street made our visit very memorable.

Hunger pangs:

Having heard rave reviews about Neapolitan pizza, we did not think much about lunch and dinner choices – it was vera pizza napoletana all the way, with _bufala DOC_Â – and we did not regret it at all :). Snack time was spent munching onÂ the deliciousÂ _baba_Â andÂ sfogliatelle, until we could eat no more.

The real “pizza”! Naples (Napoli), Italy

Sfogliatelle and baba. Foodie’s delight. Naples (Napoli), Italy

Give me more. The delicious baba. Naples (Napoli), Italy

After all that food,Â a hike up Mount Vesuvius was definitely necessary. Well, on second thoughts, an afternoon siesta seemed to be a betterÂ idea :). And then, we could gaze atÂ Vesuvio from Napoli. There seemed to be no dearth of view points.

The volcano, Mount Vesuvius:

Imposing. Ominous. Looming over the Gulf. Protective. Reassuring. Mount Vesuvius evoked a range of emotions. On one hand, there was fear – of the dangers. Vesuvio had caused much destruction in the past. And it appeared to be ominous at times. On the other hand, there was faith – in its protective shadow. Mixed feelings of the “unknown”. One day, the sky was dark and grey, the next day it was clear and blue. Each time I looked at the volcano, I was awed and enamored. Some day, we will hike up the mountain.Â On our next trip to the capital of Campania.

In the shadow of Mount Vesuvius. Napoli), Italy

The Gulf of Naples. Naples (Napoli), Italy

The Gulf of Naples. Naples (Napoli), Italy

Nativity scenes and figurines in Via San Gregorio Armeno

In the evening, we walked through the historic city center. One of theÂ narrowÂ streets was buzzing with activity. It was choc-a-bloc with stalls of nativity scenes figurines and workshops. ColorfulÂ figurines and settingsÂ depicting various real-life scenesÂ –Â from pizza-making to hanging out the laundry – occupied every inch of the stalls in Via San Gregorio Armeno. The attention to detail was extraordinary, and we spent a delightful couple of hours here. Junior had a wonderful time, keenly observingÂ every nativity scene.

Nativity scenes market. Via San Gregorio Armeno, Naples (Napoli), Italy.

Nativity scenes market. Via San Gregorio Armeno, Naples (Napoli), Italy.

 

After all the warnings from friends and well-wishers about the notorious pick-pocketing incidents in Napoli, we tried to be as cautious as possible. However, that did not deter us from making the most of our visit to the beautiful Southern city. And we loved every moment of our weekend there. The scootersÂ swerving in the streetÂ and the distant boats in the Gulf, the crowded city center andÂ the tranquil Posillipo neighborhood, the irresistible food and the magnificent views of Vesuvius… our journey had just begun.

Boats and Vesuvio. Naples (Napoli), Italy

Piazza Plebiscito. Naples (Napoli), Italy

item.title: A â€œWallâ€ of a Time at Lucca
item.description:
Lucca, Italy

During conversations with friends in Italy (over a cup of cappuccino, of course :)), a popular topic of discussion is the charming cities of this country. And one town that many folks have fallen in love with, is Lucca. Reason enough to plan a getaway to the Tuscan town.

In the regional train from Florence to Lucca, we rarely tookÂ our eyes offÂ the windowsÂ during ourÂ journey thoughÂ the picturesqueÂ Tuscan countryside.Â TheÂ first signs of spring were already visibleÂ –Â bright yellow flowers peeking out fromÂ verdant gentle slopes, hidden birds whistling melodiesÂ from the branches of a tall tree, a brook of clear water gurgling on its way through a field… and passengers having loud animated discussions about how they would spend the day in Lucca.

Thus began our weekend in Lucca. A weekend of walking on theÂ walls surrounding the old city, climbing a medieval tower with oak trees at the top, living at the site of an ancient Roman amphitheater.

 

Walking On the Walls:

The old town is entirely surrounded by walled fortifications (perimeter of approximately 4 km) that are very well-maintained. The wide walls are aÂ popular location for jogging, cycling and walking. We enjoyed long walks on the wall, played in the park (on the wall, yes!), peered at ruins, halted at every bastion and gate, ooh-ed and aah-ed at the picturesque vistas, soaked in the sunshine and got soaked in a light drizzle :).

 

Walls of Lucca, Italy

Ruins. Walls of Lucca, Italy

Walls of Lucca, Italy

Walls of Lucca, Italy

Walls of Lucca, Italy

Walls of Lucca, Italy

The path is mine. Walls of Lucca, Italy.

 

Climbing and Counting: AtÂ the Torre Guinigi

Several medieval towers dot the skyline of Lucca. Among them, the Torre Guinigi is easily identifiable owing to the oak trees that adorn its top. Junior learnt counting beyond the number 100 as he happily counted the steps on our way up the tower. Climbing and counting – two of his favorite activities – kept him engaged during the ascent. Gusty winds made it chilly at the top of the tower, but that did not deter us from admiring the views over the rooftops of the medieval city. Paintings inside the tower narrate the storyÂ of Lucca over the centuries.

 

Torre Guinigi, Lucca, Italy

That-a-way. Torre Guinigi, Lucca, Italy

Higher and higher. Torre Guinigi, Lucca, Italy.

Atop the Torre Guinigi. Lucca, Italy.

Torre Guinigi. Lucca, Italy

We had a “wall” of a time exploringÂ Lucca. Our apartment, Bed&Breakfast Anfiteatro, was at the site of an ancient Roman amphitheather. This cosy accomodation,Â overlooking the picturesque Piazza dell’Anfiteatro, was icing on the cake.

P.S. Speaking of food, we tried the typical “zuppa di farro” a couple of times, and loved it!

item.title: In the Medieval City of Siena: â€œTheâ€ Piazza and a Fortezza
item.description:
Keep gazing. View of Siena from the Fortezza Medicea, Siena

Spotting the contrade while walking in the streets of the historic center of SienaÂ was a fun way to explore the Tuscan city.

But, of course, we had “bigger” sights toÂ discover. And as always, there was something in itÂ for each of us.

 

“The” Piazza del Campo

The Piazza del Campo was a stone’s throw (ok, maybe just a little bit more) away from our hotel, the B&B Piazza Duomo.

A hop, skip, and jump away…

What lies ahead? Historic center, Siena

Piazza del Campo, Siena

Palazzo Pubblico, Piazza del Campo, Siena

Lo and behold, the magnificent medieval Piazza del Campo, the site of the Palio di Siena, stretched before us in all its glory! Junior couldn’t believe his luck – a huge, shell-shaped, sloping piazza all to himself (well, almost!) :). He got busy right away, examining and walking along the radiating lines dividing Il CampoÂ into nine sections. B and I had ample time to walk around and admire the heart of Siena. The Torre del Mangia stretched high above us, almost reaching for the sky. The Palazzo Pubblico and other buildings surrounding the square were awash in the afternoon sunlight. The Fonte Gaia (a reproduction; the original is in a museum at Siena) attracted several photographers and visitors.

As evening set in, families walked around the square, gelato in hand (duh! :)), exchanging greetings with friends. A few young students were engrossed in sketching the piazza and its buildings. A bunch of kids squealed and ran without a care in the world (that’s what I love about piazzas in Italy!).

 

Palazzo Pubblico, Piazza del Campo, Siena

Palazzo Pubblico, Piazza del Campo, Siena

Hello, up there! Torre del Mangia, Piazza del Campo, Siena

Fonte Gaia, Piazza del Campo, Siena

Fortezza Medicea

On a bright Sunday morning, we walked across the historic center (after a brief halt atÂ the Duomo) to bask in the outdoorsÂ at the Fortezza Medicea (free entry!). This fort, with origins dating back to the 16th century, provided Junior all the open space he needed and offered us pretty vistas all around – of hills in the distance and of the beautiful historic center of Siena. As locals enjoyed theirÂ morning walk or jogÂ and kids pedaled on their “two-wheelers”, we strolled along the periphery of the walls, explored the little amphitheater in the same complex, marveled at the picture-perfect views of the centerÂ of Siena.

 

Duomo, Siena

Duomo, Siena

Soak up the sunshine! Fortezza Medicea, Siena

View from Fortezza Medicea, Siena

Fortezza Medicea, Siena

Fortezza Medicea, Siena

Amphitheater, Fortezza Medicea, Siena

View of Siena from the Fortezza Medicea, Siena

And then… it was time to bid adieu to the beautiful city. Oh, well, before that… A smallÂ park and pond outside the fort were a mandatory pit-stop for the baby of our family (he would definitely disagree about the “baby” bit :); well, the “little boy” of our family). So, after that little halt,Â we wavedÂ goodbye to the swans, pigeons, turtles… and Siena.
